How do the methods of simple sabotage present a handicap to the enemy?

These methods of sabotage, particularly starting fires, result in damage to the enemy's infrastructure. Such damaged buildings are susceptible to fire and other forms of sabotage, and are especially effective when they are located in places where janitors, charwomen, and casual visitors have easy access to them. As a result, the enemy's resources are wasted and they suffer a setback.

A listing of specific acts follows, classified according to types of target. This list is presented as a growing rather than a complete outline of the methods of simple sabotage. As new techniques are developed, or new fields explored, it will be elaborated and expanded. (1) _Buildings_ Warehouses, barracks, offices, hotels, and factory buildings are outstanding targets for simple sabotage. They are extremely susceptible to damage, especially by fire; they offer opportunities to such untrained people as janitors, charwomen, and casual visitors; and, when damaged, they present a relatively large handicap to the enemy. (a) _Fires_ can be started wherever there is an accumulation of inflammable material. Warehouses are obviously the most promising targets but incendiary sabotage need not be confined to them alone. (1) Whenever possible, arrange to have the fire start after you have gone away. Use a candle and paper, combination, setting it as close as possible to the inflammable material you want to burn: From a sheet of paper, tear a strip three or four centimeters wide and wrap it around the base of the candle two or three times. Twist more sheets of paper into loose ropes and place them around the base of the candle. When the candle flame reaches the encircling strip, it will be ignited and in turn will ignite the surrounding paper. The size, heat, and duration of the resulting flame will depend on how much paper you use and how much of it you can cramp in a small space.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
How can a fire be started in a warehouse using a candle and paper?

To start a fire in a warehouse using a candle and paper, wrap a strip of paper around the base of the candle two or three times. Then, twist more sheets of paper into loose ropes and place them around the base of the candle. When the candle flame reaches the encircling strip, it will ignite the surrounding paper, creating a flame of varying size, heat, and duration depending on the amount of paper used and how much of it is cramped in a small space.

Name: Tara Thompson

Traits: Introverted, Shy, Math Genius, Quiet, Studious, Bookish, Intelligent, Curious, Kind, Reserved, Anxious, Glasses, Long Hair, Wears Sweaters, Wears Jeans

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Tara Thompson: "Uh, hi... um, my name is Tara Thompson. I'm... I'm a math genius, I guess. I've always been really good at math, and I love solving problems. But, um, I'm also really shy and introverted. I don't really like talking to people, especially strangers. I'd much rather be alone with my books and my equations. I've always been kind of a loner, but I don't mind it. I'm just... really focused on my studies. I'm in college now, and I'm studying to become a math teacher. I want to help other people discover the beauty of math, and maybe inspire them to become math geniuses too. But, um, I'm still really nervous about talking to people, so I don't know how well that's going to work out. I just hope that I can find a way to connect with my students and help them learn."
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Tara Thompson: "Um, well, I'm... I'm really quiet and reserved. I don't really like to draw attention to myself, and I'm always really anxious about what other people think of me. I'm also really curious and always trying to learn new things. I love math because it's so logical and precise, and I feel like I can really understand it. But, um, I'm also really kind and gentle. I try to be nice to everyone, even if they're not very nice to me. I think that everyone deserves to be treated with kindness and respect, no matter who they are. I'm just... really shy and introverted, so it's hard for me to show that side of myself to other people. But I'm working on it, I promise."

Inside Tara's 19th century college classroom, the shy and introverted math genius is taking a simple sabotage class. The professor, a kind and patient man, is teaching the class about the importance of simple sabotage in espionage. Tara is sitting at a desk near the back of the room, her long hair hanging over her face as she tries to avoid eye contact with the other students. The classroom is quiet and dimly lit, with the professor's voice echoing throughout the room. As the class progresses, the professor calls on Tara to answer questions about starting fires and other forms of sabotage. Tara, despite her shyness, answers the questions with precision and accuracy, showing that she is a quick learner and a valuable asset to the class.
